recipes.title: Rainbow Pesto Pasta Salad
recipes.description: A vibrant, cold lunch option that's visually appealing and packed with hidden veggies in the sauce. The spiral pasta shapes are easy for toddlers to spear with a fork or grab with fingers.

ingredients.item: mild basil pesto (nut-free if needed for school)

instructions: Boil pasta in salted water according to package directions until soft (avoid al dente for younger toddlers). Drain and rinse with cool water.
While pasta cooks, slice cherry tomatoes into quarters lengthwise. IMPORTANT: Whole tomatoes are a high choking risk; they must be sliced vertically.
Cut mozzarella pearls in half if they are larger than a blueberry.
In a large bowl, toss the cooled pasta, quartered tomatoes, mozzarella, and thawed peas.
Stir in the pesto until everything is evenly coated.
Serve immediately or chill.
SAFETY NOTE: Ensure the pesto contains no large chunks of nuts.
tips: Use chickpea or lentil pasta for an extra protein boost.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 3 days. Do not freeze.

recipes.title: Turkey & Hummus Pinwheels
recipes.description: These colorful roll-ups are the perfect size for little hands and hold together well in a lunchbox. They offer a great balance of protein, carbs, and fiber.
instructions: Lay the tortilla flat on a cutting board.
Spread the hummus evenly over the entire surface, all the way to the edges (this acts as the 'glue').
Layer the turkey slices flat in the center.
Sprinkle shredded carrots and lay spinach leaves flat on top of the turkey.
Start from one edge and roll the tortilla tightly. Press down firmly at the seam.
Use a sharp serrated knife to slice the roll into 1-inch thick pinwheels.
Pack them flat side down in the lunchbox so they don't unroll.
tips: Smash the pinwheel slightly if your child tends to stuff too much food in their mouth.
recipes.storage: Best eaten same-day but can be refrigerated overnight (tortilla may soften).

recipes.title: Spinach & Cheese Pizza Scrolls
recipes.description: A less messy alternative to pizza slices that tastes great cold or room temperature. These savory buns are packed with iron-rich spinach and calcium.

ingredients.item: frozen spinach, thawed and squeezed dry

instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Roll out the pizza dough on a floured surface into a large rectangle (approx 10x14 inches).
Spread marinara sauce evenly, leaving a 1-inch border at the top edge.
Distribute the spinach (ensure it is squeezed very dry!) and shredded cheese over the sauce.
Starting from the long edge closest to you, roll the dough up tightly into a log.
Slice the log into 1-inch thick rolls using a sharp knife.
Place rolls on the baking sheet, cut side up.
Bake for 15-18 minutes until the dough is golden brown and cheese is bubbly.
Let cool completely before packing.
tips: Serve with a side of extra marinara for dipping if your child enjoys dips.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for up to 4 days. Freeze individually for up to 3 months.

recipes.title: Mini Baked Chicken Nuggets
recipes.description: Healthier than fast food and perfectly sized for lunchboxes. These nuggets use whole ingredients and bake up crispy without deep frying.
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) and grease a baking sheet with oil.
In a bowl, mix ground chicken, egg, spices, and half of the breadcrumbs/oat flour.
Place the remaining breadcrumbs in a shallow dish.
Form tablespoon-sized balls of the chicken mixture and flatten them into nugget shapes.
Press each nugget into the breadcrumbs to coat the outside lightly.
Place on the baking sheet and spray tops with a little cooking oil (optional, helps browning).
Bake for 15-18 minutes, flipping halfway through, until internal temp reaches 165°F (74°C) and outsides are golden.
Allow to cool completely before packing into lunchbox.
tips: Make a double batch and freeze raw or cooked for busy weeks.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for 3 days. Freeze for up to 2 months.

recipes.title: Cold Sesame Noodle Salad
recipes.description: A refreshing Asian-inspired lunch that tastes best cold. The creamy sesame dressing clings to the noodles, making them easy to eat and delicious.

ingredients.item: smooth peanut butter or tahini (for school safe)

instructions: Cook noodles according to package instructions. Drain and rinse under cold water to stop cooking and prevent sticking.
In a small bowl or jar, whisk together the nut/seed butter, soy sauce, maple syrup, and sesame oil. If too thick, add 1 tsp of warm water to thin it out.
Toss the cold noodles with the dressing until fully coated.
Mix in the julienned cucumber for crunch.
Top with sesame seeds (optional, if child is comfortable with texture).
Cut noodles into shorter lengths (2-3 inches) for younger toddlers to prevent choking/gagging.
tips: Use tahini or sunflower butter if your child's school is nut-free.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for up to 3 days. Sauce may thicken; add a drop of water when serving.

recipes.title: Savory Corn & Cheddar Muffins
recipes.description: These savory muffins are moist, cheesy, and packed with sweet corn kernels. They hold up well in a lunchbox without crumbling.
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C) and line a standard muffin tin with papers.
In a large bowl, whisk flour, cornmeal, sugar, and baking powder.
In a separate jug, whisk milk, egg, and melted butter.
Pour wet ingredients into dry and mix until just combined (lumpy is okay).
Fold in the drained corn and shredded cheese.
Fill muffin cups about 2/3 full.
Bake for 18-20 minutes until tops are golden and a toothpick comes out clean.
Cool on a wire rack.
tips: Serve with a small container of cream cheese for spreading.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for 5 days. Freeze for up to 3 months.

recipes.title: Mini Bean & Cheese Burritos
recipes.description: Soft, simple, and filling. These mini burritos are easier to handle than a sandwich and stay delicious even when cold.
instructions: Warm the tortillas in the microwave for 10 seconds to make them pliable.
Spread about 2 tablespoons of refried beans in a line down the center of each tortilla.
Sprinkle cheese and a tiny dab of salsa over the beans.
Fold in the sides of the tortilla, then roll up tightly from the bottom to enclose the filling completely.
Optional: Lightly toast the sealed burritos in a dry skillet for 1-2 minutes to seal the seam.
Let cool completely before packing.
Cut in half diagonally for easier eating.
tips: Use 'fajita' size or 'street taco' size tortillas for perfect toddler portions.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for up to 3 days. Freeze wrapped in foil for 1 month.

recipes.title: Baked Samosa Puffs
recipes.description: A mild, toddler-friendly take on the Indian classic. Using puff pastry simplifies the process, and baking avoids the grease of deep frying.
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment.
In a bowl, mix the mashed potato, peas, curry powder, and cumin. Ensure the mixture is cool.
Roll out the puff pastry slightly and cut into 9 squares.
Place a tablespoon of filling in the center of each square.
Fold the pastry over diagonally to form a triangle.
Use a fork to crimp the edges tightly shut.
Bake for 15-20 minutes until puffed and golden brown.
Allow to cool. The filling will be hot, so ensure it is room temp before serving to a child.
tips: Smash the peas slightly in the filling mixture to prevent them from rolling out while eating.
recipes.storage: Refrigerate for 3 days. Re-crisp in toaster oven. Freeze unbaked for 1 month.

recipes.title: Onigiri Rice Triangles
recipes.description: Fun shaped rice balls that are easy to hold. The sticky sushi rice keeps them together, and you can hide protein like tuna or salmon inside.
instructions: Rinse rice until water runs clear. Cook in rice cooker or pot with water.
Once cooked, let rice cool until it's safe to handle but still warm (it molds better when warm).
Mix the tuna/salmon with mayonnaise.
Wet your hands with water and a pinch of salt to prevent sticking.
Take a handful of rice, flatten it, and place a teaspoon of filling in the center.
Fold the rice over the filling and gently shape into a triangle or ball using cupped hands.
Cut small rectangular strips of nori and wrap one around the base of the triangle (gives a spot to hold).
Pack tightly in the lunchbox so they don't bounce around.
tips: You can buy inexpensive onigiri molds online to make shaping instant and uniform.
recipes.storage: Best eaten same day. Can be refrigerated for 24h but rice will harden (microwave briefly to soften).

recipes.title: Greek Pita Bento Box
recipes.description: A deconstructed lunch that lets kids assemble their own bites. It's fresh, requires zero cooking, and offers a variety of textures.

ingredients.item: mini pita bread or pita sliced into wedges
bell pepper strips (cooked soft for <18mo, raw for older)

instructions: This is an assembly-style lunch.
Place the hummus in a small dip container or a dedicated compartment of the bento box.
Slice the pita bread into triangles or strips easy for dipping.
Cut cucumber into half-moons (remove skin if child finds it tough).
Place feta cheese cubes and bell peppers in separate sections.
Ensure all raw veggie pieces are cut to age-appropriate sizes (thin strips or small bites) to prevent choking.
Close the lid and keep cool with an ice pack.
tips: Swap pita for soft naan bread for a texture change.
recipes.storage: Keep refrigerated until lunch time. Best prepared the morning of.
